subject: Tighten up overall metadata size tests
commit_message:
Tighten up overall metadata size tests

Overall metadata size constraint is enforced in the container and account
backends as well as in the proxy controllers. Whereas the proxy controller
can check that constraints are not exceeded by a single PUT or POST request,
the backend checks that constraints are not exceeded by the aggregate of all
PUTs and POSTs.

The current functional tests only exercise the proxy controller checks, since
they test for a 400 when sending excessive metadata in a single POST. This patch
adds a test for a 400 when a single metadata item in a POST causes the backend
aggregate constraints check to go over limit.

The extra coverage of the new assertions can be seen by modifying
swift/common/db.DatabasBroker.validate_metadata() to always return None
immediately - only the new assertions fail when functests are run.

The neutron-ovs-cleanup service is meant to run at boot to tear down ovs
interfaces created by Neutron.  The service exits right after start when

puppet was starting this service every time it runs, which would
completely disable Neutron networking.

subject: Fixing concurrency bug in heat deployer
commit_message:
Fixing concurrency bug in heat deployer

Problem:
We want to ensure that only one assembly is in a READY state
for an app. This is to ensure that Solum does not keep around
more heat stacks than are necessary. If there are more than one
assemblies then there are that many number of heat stacks,
which we want to avoid.

So the solution that we came up with is to delete other
READY assemblies when a new assembly has become READY.

However, this solution as is currently implemented
has concurrency issues in the situation when there are multiple
deployers in the system. In our testing we have seen both of
the following:
(a) when two assembly create are triggered in quick succession both
    are deleted
(b) when two assembly creates are triggered in quick succession
    none is deleted

This patch fixes the concurrency issue to ensure that both the
above situations don't arise.

The fix for (a) is to use the 'created_at' timestamp when deleting
assemblies. The idea is to delete all the READY assemblies which
have created_at timestamp which is smaller than the newly created
assemblies' timestamp. The reason this is correct is because there
will be only one READY assembly which will have the highest created_at
timestamp (because we are using a single database). So this assembly
will end up deleting other assemblies which are READY and have a
smaller (more recent) created_at timestamp.

The fix for (b) is to perform the database writes to update an
assembly's status in a synchronous manner in the deployer itself.
Current code performs this update in an asynchronous manner via the
conductor. In a multiple deployer scenario this asynchronicity causes
race conditions which leads to situations like (b).

Closes-Bug: #1457200
Change-Id: I3482399fb08ebe19870f6dae69e2edc2a0c07685

commit_message:
Eventlet green threads not released back to pool

Presently, the wsgi server allows persist connections hence even after
the response is sent to the client, it doesn't close the client socket
connection.
Because of this problem, the green thread is not released back to the pool.

In order to close the client socket connection explicitly after the
response is sent and read successfully by the client, you simply have to
set keepalive to False when you create a wsgi server.

Icehouse backport note: socket_timeout was dropped, it was introduced
in 0.14[*] and Icehouse eventlet lower bound is 0.13

[*] https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/7d4916f01462de09cb58853d9de2e85777c2ad5b

subject: Fix continuation line under/over indented problems
commit_message:
Fix continuation line under/over indented problems

When you are writing a multiple method invocation (or other similar
syntax)

```
obj.method(argument1,
           argument2,
           ...)
```

If you put argument1 in the first line, the following lines should have
the same hanging distance to argument1.

If you put argument1 in the second line, the hanging distance should
always be four.

```
obj.method(
    argument1,
    argument2,
    ...
)
```

Otherwise PEP8 would complain for continuation line under/over indented
problems. See below for more details

https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#indentation

This patch fixes all the continuation line indentation problems and
enables related checks in tox.ini.

Closes-bug: #1459514

subject: Refactor: Join multiple criteria together
commit_message:
Refactor: Join multiple criteria together

Filtering criterion in the method of "Query.filter_by()" or
"Query.filter()" introduced by SQLAlchemy supports to join
multiple criteria together instead of join each criteria
separately.

The motivation to make this change includes,
1. The docstring in the SQLAlchemy tell us the usage,
" Multiple criteria are joined together by AND::

   session.query(MyClass).\\
      filter(MyClass.name == 'some name', MyClass.id > 5)"

or
" Multiple criteria are joined together by AND::

   session.query(MyClass).\\
      filter_by(name = 'some name', id = 5)
"

Since SQLAlchemy provides this interface, this should has
its benefit from introducing this method, the direct impact
is we needn't build the query statement repetitively.

2. The change make the code looks more concise.

subject: Remove use of contextlib.nested (db-tests)
commit_message:
Remove use of contextlib.nested (db-tests)

Removed use of contextlib.nested call from codebase, as it has been
deprecated since Python 2.7.

There are also known issues with contextlib.nested that were addressed
by the native support for multiple "with" variables. For instance, if
the first object is created but the second one throws an exception,
the first object's __exit__ is never called. For more information see

Commit 3e42c7ae3f7a9353834c8c9c4dc79ee39dd0783b changed where the Hyper-V
VM configuration files are stored. The files are being stored in the same
folder as the instance. Performing a cold resize / migration will cause a
os.rename call on the instance's folder, which fails as long as there are
configuration files used by Hyper-V in that folder, thus resulting in a
failed migration and the instance ending up in ERROR state.

Hyper-V configuration files are stored in a subfolder of the instance's
folder (e.g.: C:\OpenStack\Instances\instance-000000b6\Virtual Machines).

This commit makes sure that Hyper-V configuration files are not being

subject: Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better
commit_message:
Allow SAIO to answer is_local_device() better

Common SAIO setups have multiple "servers" all on the same host with
different ports for the different "servers" (which happen to match the
IPs specified in the rings for the devices on each of those "servers").

This breaks down if you want to set up the SAIO to have one
object-server per disk.

However, you can configure the SAIO to have different localhost IP
addresses (e.g. 127.0.0.1, 127.0.0.2, etc.) in the ring and in the
servers' config files' bind_ip setting.

This new whataremyips() implementation combined with a little plumbing
allows is_local_device() to accurately answer, even on an SAIO.

In the default case (an unspecified bind_ip defaults to '0.0.0.0') as
well as an explict "bind to everything" like '0.0.0.0' or '::',
whataremyips() behaves as it always has, returning all IP addresses for
the server.

Also updated probe tests to handle each "server" in the SAIO having a
unique IP address.

subject: Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec class
commit_message:
Scheduler: Introduce a FilterRequestSpec class

As part of Scheduler refactoring, we are planning to move all the data
request_specs dict to NovaObjects. This effort is about solidifying the
external interfaces of the scheduler component, in hopes of moving it
out of the Nova project.

This patch can be seen as a small step in that direction, for the
purpose of using a more object like interface in the scheduler code
(mostly filters at this point).

As a basic example: We have a need to detect if the request sent to the
scheduler related to an instance attempts to change the flavor. We add
this functionality as a method on an object that wraps the request_spec
dictionary, that we can now use in filter code to make decisions.

With this we get to iterate over the objects API while punting the work
of actually changing the RPC API to use new objects to a later series,
while avoiding the need to add messy functionality as utility methods that
deal with request_spec dictionaries that are on their way out.
